title: European Union law
context: While the Treaties and Regulations will have direct effect (if clear, unconditional and immediate), Directives do not generally give citizens (as opposed to the member state) standing to sue other citizens. In theory, this is because TFEU article 288 says Directives are addressed to the member states and usually "leave to the national authorities the choice of form and methods" to implement. In part this reflects that directives often create minimum standards, leaving member states to apply higher standards. For example, the Working Time Directive requires that every worker has at least 4 weeks paid holidays each year, but most member states require more than 28 days in national law. However, on the current position adopted by the Court of Justice, citizens have standing to make claims based on national laws that implement Directives, but not from Directives themselves. Directives do not have so called "horizontal" direct effect (i.e. between non-state parties). This view was instantly controversial, and in the early 1990s three Advocate Generals persuasively argued that Directives should create rights and duties for all citizens. The Court of Justice refused, but there are five large exceptions.

5. Directives generally do not create horizontal direct effect, meaning they do not give citizens the rights or duties in relation to other non-state parties.

7. There are five large exceptions to the Court of Justice's stance, which may allow citizens certain rights derived from Directives.

1. Direct effects of Treaties and Regulations: Treaties and Regulations are legal instruments with direct effect, which means they have immediate, unconditional, and clear impact on individuals or organizations within the European Union.
2. Directives and citizens: Unlike Treaties and Regulations, Directives generally do not provide citizens the right to sue other citizens, but they may have implications for individual rights and responsibilities within member states.
3. Flexibility for member states: Directives usually leave the choice of form and methods to member states for implementation, as required by TFEU article 288. This flexibility allows member states to adopt their preferred approaches and adapt the directives to their specific contexts.
4. Minimum standards: Directives often establish minimum standards, allowing member states to implement higher standards. For example, the Working Time Directive sets a minimum requirement of 28 days of paid holidays annually, but most member states implement more extensive leave provisions in their national laws.
5. Standing of citizens: Citizens do not have standing to directly sue other citizens based on Directives, but they can rely on national laws that implement Directives as a basis for their claims. This means that legal recourse for citizens depends on the level of implementation achieved by the member states.
6. Horizontal direct effect: Directives do not have "horizontal" direct effect, which means they do not create rights and duties between non-state parties. This distinction was initially controversial and continues to be a source of debate in the legal community.
7. Advocate General views: In the early 1990s, three Advocate Generals argued that Directives should create rights and duties for all citizens, and their views reflect the complex nature of European Union law, which often involves legal interpretations and multiple perspectives.
8. Exceptions to the rule: There are five large exceptions to the general rule that citizens do not have standing to sue based on Directives, which suggests that there may be situations where legal recourse is available to individuals or organizations, even without direct standing. These exceptions may include specific cases, such as breaches of fundamental rights, cases involving discrimination, or situations where member states fail to implement Directives properly.

title: 1973 oil crisis
context: Federal safety standards, such as NHTSA Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standard 215 (pertaining to safety bumpers), and compacts like the 1974 Mustang I were a prelude to the DOT "downsize" revision of vehicle categories. By 1977, GM's full-sized cars reflected the crisis. By 1979, virtually all "full-size" American cars had shrunk, featuring smaller engines and smaller outside dimensions. Chrysler ended production of their full-sized luxury sedans at the end of the 1981 model year, moving instead to a full front-wheel drive lineup for 1982 (except for the M-body Dodge Diplomat/Plymouth Gran Fury and Chrysler New Yorker Fifth Avenue sedans).

title: Genghis Khan
context: Genghis Khan is regarded as one of the prominent leaders in Mongolia's history. He is responsible for the emergence of the Mongols as a political and ethnic identity because there was no unified identity between the tribes that had cultural similarity. He reinforced many Mongol traditions and provided stability and unity during a time of almost endemic warfare between tribes. He is also given credit for the introduction of the traditional Mongolian script and the creation of the Ikh Zasag (Great Administration), the first written Mongolian law. "Ikh Zasag law adopted during Genghis Khanâ€™s time in Mongolia had points to punish illegal matters related to corruption and bribery very heavily," Mongolian President Tsakhiagiin Elbegdorj noted. President Elbegdorj sees Genghis Khan as a leader from whom to learn for anti-corruption efforts as Genghis Khan sought equal protection under the law for all citizens regardless of status or wealth. "Chinggis (Genghis Khan)...was a man who deeply realized that the justice begins and consolidates with the equality of law, and not with the distinctions between people. He was a man who knew that the good laws and rules lived longer than fancy palaces," Elbegdorj said in his speech on the 850th anniversary of Chinggis Khaan's birth. In summary, Mongolians see him as the fundamental figure in the founding of the Mongol Empire and therefore the basis for Mongolia as a country.

Passage:
National Archives
British settlers established the first permanent white settlement in St. George's on the southern coast of the island in 1612, which was also the first permanent English settlement in the Western Hemisphere. Since then, the island has been under English, Jamaican, and British control, becoming the British colony of "Bermuda" in 1684. The colony was renamed Bermuda in 1977, in anticipation of becoming an independent state after decades of negotiations with the United Kingdom. When the negotiations faltered in 2003, Bermuda took the name back to "Bermuda", but still remains a British Overseas Territory.
The British established the Bermuda colonies to use for trade and profit. Although they were under British control, Bermuda was settled by Dutch, French, Spanish, and Portuguese settlers, as well as various small indigenous tribes. In the 17th and 18th centuries, numerous other European powers set up colonies on the island, primarily in the south. Many of these colonies were ceded or eventually sold to the British. The British government decided to keep a large population of Africans, and later slaves, on the island for the purpose of working the sugar plantations. The British government did not recognize the 'Bermuda-born' majority as British citizens because of their African ancestry. A large portion of the population of Bermuda is of African descent, resulting in a majority Black population.

As a result of British colonization, Bermuda became the second-most densely populated colony in the New World, after Martinique.
Bermuda is home to an estimated 1,159 species of insects, making it one of the most diverse insect faunas in the world. However, the island is also home to many species of reptiles, including sea turtles, snakes, and lizards. On land, there are at least 75 known species of butterflies and moths, many of which are endemic to the region and found nowhere else. The Bermuda petrel, an endangered seabird species, is also endemic to the island, and its recovery efforts have been successful. Bermuda is also home to many species of birds, such as the Bermuda cedar waxwing, which is found only on the island, and the Bermuda warbler, which is considered to be one of the rarest birds in the world.
There are at least 25 species of mammals found on Bermuda, including many small mammals, such as bats, shrews, and dormice. Larger mammals, such as the Bermuda feral pig and the Bermuda rabbit, were introduced to the island by human settlers. The introduced feral pig and rabbit have caused damage to the island's ecosystem by competing with native species for resources and altering habitats.

Chloroplast
While primary chloroplasts have a double membrane from their cyanobacterial ancestor, secondary chloroplasts have additional membranes outside of the original two, as a result of the secondary endosymbiotic event, when a nonphotosynthetic eukaryote engulfed a chloroplast-containing alga but failed to digest itâ€”much like the cyanobacterium at the beginning of this story. title: Yuan dynasty
context: The system of bureaucracy created by Kublai Khan reflected various cultures in the empire, including that of the Han Chinese, Khitans, Jurchens, Mongols, and Tibetan Buddhists. While the official terminology of the institutions may indicate the government structure was almost purely that of native Chinese dynasties, the Yuan bureaucracy actually consisted of a mix of elements from different cultures. The Chinese-style elements of the bureaucracy mainly came from the native Tang, Song, as well as Khitan Liao and Jurchen Jin dynasties. Chinese advisers such as Liu Bingzhong and Yao Shu gave strong influence to Kublai's early court, and the central government administration was established within the first decade of Kublai's reign. This government adopted the traditional Chinese tripartite division of authority among civil, military, and censorial offices, including the Central Secretariat (Zhongshu Sheng) to manage civil affairs, the Privy Council (Chinese: æ¨žå¯†é™¢) to manage military affairs, and the Censorate to conduct internal surveillance and inspection. The actual functions of both central and local government institutions, however, showed a major overlap between the civil and military jurisdictions, due to the Mongol traditional reliance on military institutions and offices as the core of governance. Nevertheless, such a civilian bureaucracy, with the Central Secretariat as the top institution that was (directly or indirectly) responsible for most other governmental agencies (such as the traditional Chinese-style Six Ministries), was created in China. At various times another central government institution called the Department of State Affairs (Shangshu Sheng) that mainly dealt with finance was established (such as during the reign of KÃ¼lÃ¼g Khan or Emperor Wuzong), but was usually abandoned shortly afterwards.

The principle behind vaccination (also called immunization) is to introduce an antigen from a pathogen in order to stimulate the immune system and develop specific immunity against that particular pathogen without causing disease associated with that organism. This deliberate induction of an immune response is successful because it exploits the natural specificity of the immune system, as well as its inducibility. With infectious disease remaining one of the leading causes of death in the human population, vaccination represents the most effective manipulation of the immune system mankind has developed.

title: Victoria (Australia)
context: As of August 2010, Victoria had 1,548 public schools, 489 Catholic schools and 214 independent schools. Just under 540,800 students were enrolled in public schools, and just over 311,800 in private schools. Over 61 per cent of private students attend Catholic schools. More than 462,000 students were enrolled in primary schools and more than 390,000 in secondary schools. Retention rates for the final two years of secondary school were 77 per cent for public school students and 90 per cent for private school students. Victoria has about 63,519 full-time teachers.

Due to FCC ownership rules, the transaction, which was to include the purchase of three RCA stations by Noble, would require him to resell his station with the FCC's approval. The Commission authorized the transaction on October 12, 1943. Soon afterward, the Blue Network was purchased by the new company Noble founded, the American Broadcasting System. Noble subsequently acquired the rights to the "American Broadcasting Company" name from George B. Storer in 1944; its parent company adopted the corporate name American Broadcasting Companies, Inc. Woods retained his position as president and CEO of ABC until December 1949, and was subsequently promoted to vice-chairman of the board before leaving ABC altogether on June 30, 1951.

context: In past times, corporal punishment (spanking or paddling or caning or strapping or birching the student in order to cause physical pain) was one of the most common forms of school discipline throughout much of the world. Most Western countries, and some others, have now banned it, but it remains lawful in the United States following a US Supreme Court decision in 1977 which held that paddling did not violate the US Constitution.

title: Scottish Parliament
context: The Presiding Officer (or Deputy Presiding Officer) decides who speaks in chamber debates and the amount of time for which they are allowed to speak. Normally, the Presiding Officer tries to achieve a balance between different viewpoints and political parties when selecting members to speak. Typically, ministers or party leaders open debates, with opening speakers given between 5 and 20 minutes, and succeeding speakers allocated less time. The Presiding Officer can reduce speaking time if a large number of members wish to participate in the debate. Debate is more informal than in some parliamentary systems. Members may call each other directly by name, rather than by constituency or cabinet position, and hand clapping is allowed. Speeches to the chamber are normally delivered in English, but members may use Scots, Gaelic, or any other language with the agreement of the Presiding Officer. The Scottish Parliament has conducted debates in the Gaelic language.

prompt:
Let's read the following passage and produce a long list of implications derived directly or indirectly from the content.

Passage:
Scottish Parliament
The Presiding Officer (or Deputy Presiding Officer) decides who speaks in chamber debates and the amount of time for which they are allowed to speak. Normally, the Presiding Officer tries to achieve a balance between different viewpoints and political parties when selecting members to speak. Typically, ministers or party leaders open debates, with opening speakers given between 5 and 20 minutes, and succeeding speakers allocated less time. The Presiding Officer can reduce speaking time if a large number of members wish to participate in the debate. Debate is more informal than in some parliamentary systems. Members may call each other directly by name, rather than by constituency or cabinet position, and hand clapping is allowed. Speeches to the chamber are normally delivered in English, but members may use Scots, Gaelic, or any other language with the agreement of the Presiding Officer. The Scottish Parliament has conducted debates in the Gaelic language.

Challenging Passages for USMLE
Genetics
While each chromosome contains a precise number of genes, the number of expressed genes is not fixed. In development, the expression of certain genes is controlled by others. Transcription factors control genesâ€™ activity by binding to the promoter region of a gene and either allowing RNA polymerase to transcribe the gene or preventing it. For instance, expression of the homeobox genes, which control whether a gene is active in the development of the head or limbs, is controlled by homeodomain proteins, transcription factors. Some transcription factors that are critical to development are of the zinc finger or homeodomain type. Nevertheless, the transcription factors and their target genes, though numerous, are not nearly enough to control every aspect of development.
Characteristics of characteristics that have heritable components are called polygenic traits. Common examples include blood type, intelligence, diabetes, and height, which all have heritable components. Blood type is a simple polygenic trait. Everyone can be Type A, Type B, Type AB, or Type O, and these are inherited as unlinked, independent factors. In contrast, the outcome of pregnancy with a diabetic mother may range from a small, unhealthy baby to a full-term, healthy baby, depending on maternal blood sugar levels, the amount of insulin the motherâ€™s pancreas produces, her weight gain during pregnancy, and her fetal blood sugar levels. With this combination of numerous influencing factors, the outcome (the polygenic trait) cannot be predicted with certainty. This represents an advantage for the organismâ€™s offspring. One out of 400 people born in the United States will develop diabetes during their lifetime, and this increase may be because of greater consumption of sugar and more obesity. However, certain heritable components are also significant. A family with diabetes might have three siblings who have the disease and one who does not. This variability might be due to one sibling having more of the heritable susceptibility to the disease. A doctor could calculate the diseaseâ€™s prevalence in the family and determine a risk level. Then she could advise the undiagnosed sibling to perform regular self-examination and have regular checkups.
Common polygenic traits, such as type 2 diabetes, are rarely all-or-none. For example, people who have type 2 diabetes may have mild symptoms, or in another case, they may have severe symptoms. These symptoms might be influenced by other health conditions such as obesity, heart disease, or high blood pressure. This may account for why some people with type 2 diabetes are able to manage the disease with diet and exercise while others may need insulin and other medications.
On the subject of medical genetics, donâ€™t forget this important fact: Mutations can affect individuals or entire species by removing important proteins from the body, or by adding harmful proteins to the body.
by: Crown & Patel.
is a gene a 'exact copy' of its 'parent' genes. meaning if Gene A makes RNA A which codes for protein A and Gene B makes RNA B which codes for protein B.
Under normal conditions, a gene does indeed function as an â€œexact copyâ€ of its parent gene during cellular processes such as transcription and translation. Here's how it typically works:

1. **DNA Replication**: When a cell divides, the DNA (genetic material) is duplicated so that each new cell receives an exact copy of the original genetic information.

2. **Transcription**: During transcription, the geneâ€”a segment of DNA containing the information for a particular proteinâ€”is copied into messenger RNA (mRNA). This process is precise and faithful, meaning the mRNA produced from a gene will mirror the genetic sequence of that gene.

3. **Translation**: The mRNA then moves into the cytoplasm, where it is translated into a protein. The mRNA is read by ribosomes, and the sequence of nucleotides in the mRNA determines the sequence of amino acids in the protein. Each amino acid is specified by a sequence of three nucleotides on the mRNA (a codon).

However, it's important to note a few exceptions where genetic information can be altered:

- **Mutations**: These are permanent changes in the DNA sequence that can occur due to errors during DNA replication or exposure to certain chemicals or radiation. Some mutations can lead to altered proteins or even entirely different proteins, potentially affecting the function of the organism.

- **Epigenetics**: This is the study of changes in gene expression that are not caused by changes in the DNA sequence itself but are influenced by factors such as environment, diet, stress, and other factors. Epigenetic modifications can affect how genes are expressed without altering the underlying DNA sequence.

- **Genetic Repeats**: Some genes contain repetitive sequences, and these can sometimes expand or contract through processes known as microsatellite instability or tandem repeat amplification.

In summary, while genes generally function as exact copies of their parent genes under normal conditions, various factors can lead to alterations in the genetic code, resulting in changes in the proteins produced by those genes.

title: Chloroplast
context: Recently, chloroplasts have caught attention by developers of genetically modified crops. Since, in most flowering plants, chloroplasts are not inherited from the male parent, transgenes in these plastids cannot be disseminated by pollen. This makes plastid transformation a valuable tool for the creation and cultivation of genetically modified plants that are biologically contained, thus posing significantly lower environmental risks. This biological containment strategy is therefore suitable for establishing the coexistence of conventional and organic agriculture. While the reliability of this mechanism has not yet been studied for all relevant crop species, recent results in tobacco plants are promising, showing a failed containment rate of transplastomic plants at 3 in 1,000,000.

Clinicians assess substance use disorders (SUDs) by interviewing and observing patients, but there is debate about the underlying mechanisms. Recent findings from Dr. Martin Scheierâ€™s research lab at Michigan State University, in collaboration with researchers from Pittsburgh, have provided new insight into how alcohol affects the ability to control negative reactions to stimuli associated with alcohol and to form new memory associations with substances. Compared to light drinkers and non-drinkers, heavy drinkers respond more slowly and experience a greater drop in subjective well-being when confronted with negative pictures related to alcohol. Moreover, heavy drinkers also exhibit slower reaction times and greater decrease in subjective well-being when learning new information about non-alcoholic substances. These results suggest that heavy drinking exacerbates the negative affective processes that mediate relapse and facilitates new memories that could increase the risk of relapse. The increased exposure to negative affective stimuli and the faster learning of salience about new drug-related cues could help explain the rapid deterioration that alcoholics experience if deprived of alcohol for short periods of time. Taken together, this research highlights the importance of identifying and addressing maladaptive affective processes related to substance use in order to develop more effective treatment strategies.

Biotechnology is the collection of scientific techniques used to modify organisms and molecules to accomplish useful tasks. Biotechnologists use genetic engineering, embryo and cell manipulation, tissue culture, fermentation, enzyme engineering, gene or cell therapy, and protein engineering to produce products such as medicine and food ingredients, and create processes such as the production of biofuels and waste treatment. Biotechnology also includes applications of these processes for diagnostic and monitoring purposes, such as the production of biological testing methods, and the application of bioprocesses to environmental issues, such as waste water treatment. Biotechnology includes biomaterials technology, which incorporates the use of living systems, synthetic biology, and materials for biomass production. Biotechnology also includes the cross-disciplinary field of bioinformatics, which uses mathematics, statistics, computer science, and engineering to model and analyze biological data. 

Biotechnology dates back thousands of years to domestication of animals, opening up agriculture for humans; the cultivation of plants for useful purposes, thus laying the foundation for the spread of civilizations. The field now includes industrial biotechnology and bioengineering, and encompasses many scientific and practical aspects of medicine, agriculture, food and nutrition, environment, energy, and information technology. Biotechnology can be used to obtain novel pharmaceuticals, pesticides, and fuels from carbon dioxide (biochemicals). Though biotechnology is often understood as referring to techniques and methods that can be performed at the cellular or molecular scale, it can also be used at a larger scale to characterize, modify, and exploit biological systems (bioreactor) for the development and production of a wide range of products, including chemicals and foods, and to improve plant and animal health and welfare, and the sustainability of agriculture. Biotechnology has applications in all areas of society, including energy production, chemical manufacturing, environmental remediation, and information technology. It has also had significant impacts on health care with applications in many areas of biomedical science. Biotechnology is a multidisciplinary field that brings together biology, mathematics, and engineering to study and develop biological systems that can be used to solve real-world problems. This includes everything from developing new medicines to finding solutions to climate change.

title: Chloroplast
context: Like mitochondria, chloroplasts use the potential energy stored in an H+, or hydrogen ion gradient to generate ATP energy. The two photosystems capture light energy to energize electrons taken from water, and release them down an electron transport chain. The molecules between the photosystems harness the electrons' energy to pump hydrogen ions into the thylakoid space, creating a concentration gradient, with more hydrogen ions (up to a thousand times as many) inside the thylakoid system than in the stroma. The hydrogen ions in the thylakoid space then diffuse back down their concentration gradient, flowing back out into the stroma through ATP synthase. ATP synthase uses the energy from the flowing hydrogen ions to phosphorylate adenosine diphosphate into adenosine triphosphate, or ATP. Because chloroplast ATP synthase projects out into the stroma, the ATP is synthesized there, in position to be used in the dark reactions.

title: Imperialism
context: In anglophone academic works, theories regarding imperialism are often based on the British experience. The term "Imperialism" was originally introduced into English in its present sense in the late 1870s by opponents of the allegedly aggressive and ostentatious imperial policies of British prime Minister Benjamin Disraeli. It was shortly appropriated by supporters of "imperialism" such as Joseph Chamberlain. For some, imperialism designated a policy of idealism and philanthropy; others alleged that it was characterized by political self-interest, and a growing number associated it with capitalist greed. Liberal John A. Hobson and Marxist Vladimir Lenin added a more theoretical macroeconomic connotation to the term. Lenin in particular exerted substantial influence over later Marxist conceptions of imperialism with his work Imperialism, the Highest Stage of Capitalism. In his writings Lenin portrayed Imperialism as a natural extension of capitalism that arose from need for capitalist economies to constantly expand investment, material resources and manpower in such a way that necessitated colonial expansion. This conception of imperialism as a structural feature of capitalism is echoed by later Marxist theoreticians. Many theoreticians on the left have followed in emphasizing the structural or systemic character of "imperialism". Such writers have expanded the time period associated with the term so that it now designates neither a policy, nor a short space of decades in the late 19th century, but a world system extending over a period of centuries, often going back to Christopher Columbus and, in some accounts, to the Crusades. As the application of the term has expanded, its meaning has shifted along five distinct but often parallel axes: the moral, the economic, the systemic, the cultural, and the temporal. Those changes reflect - among other shifts in sensibility - a growing unease, even squeamishness, with the fact of power, specifically, Western power.

3. Despite its negative connotations, proponents of imperialism, such as Joseph Chamberlain, also used the term to describe a policy of idealism and philanthropy.
4. The term is associated with both political self-interest and capitalist greed.
5. The conceptualization of imperialism as an extension of capitalism by Marxist theorists has had a significant impact on the development of theoretical frameworks and classifications of imperialism in academic works.
6. The term is often used as a specific historical period or stage, rather than a policy or event.
7. There are multiple axes on which interpretations of imperialism shift: moral, economic, systemic, cultural, and temporal.
8. Changes in the understanding of imperialism as a concept reflect broader shifts in sensibilities related to power and Western power.
9. The term has been adopted by various theoreticians and can be categorized into different Marxist, leftist, and other interpretations.
10. The time period associated with the term imperialism has expanded, often extending back to the 15th and 16th centuries.

4. Both proponents and opponents associated imperialism with different aspects - some with political self-interest, while others viewed it as a manifestation of capitalist greed.
5. Liberal theorist John A. Hobson and Marxist Vladimir Lenin added a macroeconomic perspective to the term, significantly influencing later Marxist conceptions of imperialism.
6. Lenin's Imperialism, the Highest Stage of Capitalism was a crucial work that portrayed imperialism as a natural extension of capitalism necessitated by the expansion of material resources and wealth.
7. This Marxist perspective of imperialism as a structural feature of capitalism has had a lasting impact on later theoretical accounts of imperialism.
8. Many theoreticians on the left have adopted a systemic or structural approach to the term, extending its application over centuries or even millennia, such as from Christopher Columbus and the Crusades.
9. The changing use and meaning of "imperialism" have been influenced by broader shifts in societal sensibilities and a growing awareness of power dynamics, specifically Western power.
10. Contemporary analysis of imperialism emphasizes the moral, economic, systemic, cultural, and temporal dimensions of the concept, reflecting the complexity and multifaceted nature of imperialist practices and their historical and cultural contexts.
prompt:
Let's read the following passage and produce a long list of implications derived directly or indirectly from the content.

Passage:
Imperialism
In anglophone academic works, theories regarding imperialism are often based on the British experience. The term "Imperialism" was originally introduced into English in its present sense in the late 1870s by opponents of the allegedly aggressive and ostentatious imperial policies of British prime Minister Benjamin Disraeli. It was shortly appropriated by supporters of "imperialism" such as Joseph Chamberlain. For some, imperialism designated a policy of idealism and philanthropy; others alleged that it was characterized by political self-interest, and a growing number associated it with capitalist greed. Liberal John A. Hobson and Marxist Vladimir Lenin added a more theoretical macroeconomic connotation to the term. Lenin in particular exerted substantial influence over later Marxist conceptions of imperialism with his work Imperialism, the Highest Stage of Capitalism. In his writings Lenin portrayed Imperialism as a natural extension of capitalism that arose from need for capitalist economies to constantly expand investment, material resources and manpower in such a way that necessitated colonial expansion. This conception of imperialism as a structural feature of capitalism is echoed by later Marxist theoreticians. Many theoreticians on the left have followed in emphasizing the structural or systemic character of "imperialism". Such writers have expanded the time period associated with the term so that it now designates neither a policy, nor a short space of decades in the late 19th century, but a world system extending over a period of centuries, often going back to Christopher Columbus and, in some accounts, to the Crusades. As the application of the term has expanded, its meaning has shifted along five distinct but often parallel axes: the moral, the economic, the systemic, the cultural, and the temporal. Those changes reflect - among other shifts in sensibility - a growing unease, even squeamishness, with the fact of power, specifically, Western power.

Geneva was John Calvin's adopted home and the centre of the Calvinist movement. In Geneva, Hugues, though Catholic, was a leader of the "Confederate Party", so called because it favoured independence from the Duke of Savoy through an alliance between the city-state of Geneva and the Swiss Confederation. The move would have had the side effect of fostering relations with the Swiss. Thus, Hugues plus Eidgenosse by way of Huisgenoten supposedly became Huguenot, a nickname associating the Protestant cause with politics unpopular in France.[citation needed]

3. BPP, ZPP, and RP classes involve problems solved by probabilistic Turing machines, highlighting the role of randomness and probability in computational problems.

5. BQP and QMA are defined using quantum Turing machines, illustrating the importance of quantum computation in solving problems.
6. The class P represents problems that can be solved in polynomial time, while NP includes problems where a given solution can be verified in polynomial time.

8. The P vs NP problem, one of the most important open questions in computational complexity theory, asks whether P equals NP.

When he was criticised for inserting the word "alone" after "faith" in Romans 3:28, he replied in part: "[T]he text itself and the meaning of St. Paul urgently require and demand it. For in that very passage he is dealing with the main point of Christian doctrine, namely, that we are justified by faith in Christ without any works of the Law. ... But when works are so completely cut away â€“ and that must mean that faith alone justifies â€“ whoever would speak plainly and clearly about this cutting away of works will have to say, 'Faith alone justifies us, and not works'."

Certainly! Here are expanded implications based on the passage and additional points related to the translation process and its broader implications:

* The translation process and methodologies employed by Luther:
    * Luther translated the Bible with a focus on conveying the original meaning and intent of the text, rather than just translating word for word.
    * He worked with collaborators, such as Hans Lufft, to refine and finalize his translation.
    * Luther was meticulous about his translation, making many changes and adjustments over time to ensure accuracy and clarity.
    * His translation took into account the context and nuances of the original languages, particularly Latin and Hebrew.
    * Luther incorporated his theological beliefs into his translation, emphasizing the importance of faith alone for justification.
    * He used vernacular German, making the Bible accessible to a wider audience and fostering a more direct connection between the text and the people.
* The reception and influence of Luther's translation on the German-speaking world:
    * Luther's translation of the Bible was widely accepted and adopted in the German-speaking world, becoming the standard for many centuries.
    * It helped to promote literacy and education in the German language, as more people had access to the Bible in their native tongue.
    * The translation had a significant impact on the German language itself, influencing its development and evolution.
    * It also led to the development of other translations in other European languages, further spreading the Protestant Reformation across the continent.
    * Luther's translation contributed to the growth of Christianity in Europe, as more people were able to read and interpret the Bible for themselves.
    * The translation process itself became a model for other translators and scholars, demonstrating the importance of careful attention to detail and the value of translation in spreading religious ideas.
* Broader implications for the study and interpretation of the Bible:
    * Luther's emphasis on faith alone for justification challenged traditional Catholic doctrines, leading to significant shifts in the interpretation and understanding of the Bible.
    * His translation and the resulting debate surrounding it contributed to the development of Protestant theology and the rise of Protestant denominations.
    * Luther's translation and his emphasis on personal interpretation of the Bible helped to shape the modern approach to biblical scholarship, emphasizing the importance of individual interpretation and the role of the Bible in personal faith.
    * The translation process itself became a subject of study and analysis, with scholars examining the linguistic and theological choices made by Luther and his collaborators.
    * Luther's translation also had a lasting impact on the way people approach the study and interpretation of the Bible, encouraging readers to engage with the text critically and thoughtfully.

title: Prime number
context: Most early Greeks did not even consider 1 to be a number, so they could not consider it to be a prime. By the Middle Ages and Renaissance many mathematicians included 1 as the first prime number. In the mid-18th century Christian Goldbach listed 1 as the first prime in his famous correspondence with Leonhard Euler -- who did not agree. In the 19th century many mathematicians still considered the number 1 to be a prime. For example, Derrick Norman Lehmer's list of primes up to 10,006,721, reprinted as late as 1956, started with 1 as its first prime. Henri Lebesgue is said to be the last professional mathematician to call 1 prime. By the early 20th century, mathematicians began to accept that 1 is not a prime number, but rather forms its own special category as a "unit".

questions.question: What number did early Greeks not regard as a true number?
Who included 1 as the first prime number in the mid 18th century?
In the mid 18th century, who did not concur that 1 should be the first prime number?
How many primes were included in Derrick Norman Lehmer's list of prime numbers?
What type of number do modern mathematicians consider 1 to be?
questions.answer: its own special category as a "unit"

title: Oxygen
context: John Dalton's original atomic hypothesis assumed that all elements were monatomic and that the atoms in compounds would normally have the simplest atomic ratios with respect to one another. For example, Dalton assumed that water's formula was HO, giving the atomic mass of oxygen as 8 times that of hydrogen, instead of the modern value of about 16. In 1805, Joseph Louis Gay-Lussac and Alexander von Humboldt showed that water is formed of two volumes of hydrogen and one volume of oxygen; and by 1811 Amedeo Avogadro had arrived at the correct interpretation of water's composition, based on what is now called Avogadro's law and the assumption of diatomic elemental molecules.[a]

questions.question: What did John Dalton think that all elements were in number present in compounds?
What did Dalton think the atomic ratios were between atoms in compounds?
What was Dalton's erroneous formula for water?
What element did Gay-Lussac and von Humboldt discover was present in twice the amount of oxygen in water?
What theory was arrived at in 1811 that presented the assumption of diatomic molecules?

completions:
1. John Dalton's original hypothesis assumed that all elements existed as monatomic particles, which means he believed that each element was made up of a single type of atom.
2. Dalton also assumed that the simplest atomic ratios would be found in compounds. For example, he thought that water was composed of one part hydrogen and one part oxygen, giving the atomic mass of oxygen as 8 times that of hydrogen.
3. The acceptance of Dalton's hypothesis required the recognition that atomic ratios in compounds are not always the simplest ones, such as in the case of water where it is actually composed of two parts hydrogen and one part oxygen.
4. The discovery by Joseph Louis Gay-Lussac and Alexander von Humboldt that water is formed by combining two volumes of hydrogen and one volume of oxygen contradicted Dalton's assumption of monatomic elements and the simplicity of atomic ratios in compounds.
5. Amedeo Avogadro proposed the concept of diatomic elemental molecules, which means that some elements, like oxygen, exist as molecules made up of two atoms rather than a single atom.
6. Avogadro's interpretation of water's composition, with two parts hydrogen and one part oxygen, was based on what is now known as Avogadro's law, which states that equal volumes of gases at the same temperature and pressure contain equal numbers of molecules.
7. Avogadro's hypothesis regarding diatomic molecules was a significant departure from the prevailing notion of Dalton's atomic hypothesis and paved the way for a more accurate understanding of chemical compounds.
8. The realization that water is composed of two parts hydrogen and one part oxygen, as proposed by Avogadro, led to a better understanding of the true nature of water molecules and their role in chemical reactions.
9. The discovery of diatomic molecules has implications for the study of other chemical compounds and the atomic structure of elements, suggesting that the underlying structure of matter is more complex than initially assumed.
10. The development of a more accurate understanding of atomic structure and the behavior of elements and compounds has important implications for fields such as chemistry, physics, and engineering, as it informs our understanding of the behavior of matter on a fundamental level.
11. The acceptance of Avogadro's hypothesis and the subsequent discovery of diatomic molecules challenges the validity of John Dalton's original atomic hypothesis and highlights the importance of ongoing scientific inquiry and revision of existing theories.
12. The realization that elements can exist as diatomic molecules has implications for the stability and reactivity of various compounds, as well as the development of new materials and technologies.
13. The concept of diatomic molecules also has implications for the understanding of other chemical elements and their behavior in various environments and under different conditions.
14. Avogadro's hypothesis also implies that the atomic masses of elements must be interpreted in the context of their diatomic nature, as the mass of an individual atom may not always accurately reflect its chemical behavior in compounds.
15. The acceptance of Avogadro's interpretation of water's composition and the subsequent recognition of diatomic molecules has led to a more accurate understanding of the underlying structure of matter and the behavior of elements in chemical reactions.

title: French and Indian War
context: In the spring of 1753, Paul Marin de la Malgue was given command of a 2,000-man force of Troupes de la Marine and Indians. His orders were to protect the King's land in the Ohio Valley from the British. Marin followed the route that CÃ©loron had mapped out four years earlier, but where CÃ©loron had limited the record of French claims to the burial of lead plates, Marin constructed and garrisoned forts. He first constructed Fort Presque Isle (near present-day Erie, Pennsylvania) on Lake Erie's south shore. He had a road built to the headwaters of LeBoeuf Creek. Marin constructed a second fort at Fort Le Boeuf (present-day Waterford, Pennsylvania), designed to guard the headwaters of LeBoeuf Creek. As he moved south, he drove off or captured British traders, alarming both the British and the Iroquois. Tanaghrisson, a chief of the Mingo, who were remnants of Iroquois and other tribes who had been driven west by colonial expansion. He intensely disliked the French (whom he accused of killing and eating his father). Traveling to Fort Le Boeuf, he threatened the French with military action, which Marin contemptuously dismissed.

In the spring of 1753, Paul Marin de la Malgue was given command of a 2,000-man force of Troupes de la Marine and Indians. His orders were to protect the King's land in the Ohio Valley from the British. Marin followed the route that CÃ©loron had mapped out four years earlier, but where CÃ©loron had limited the record of French claims to the burial of lead plates, Marin constructed and garrisoned forts. He first constructed Fort Presque Isle (near present-day Erie, Pennsylvania) on Lake Erie's south shore. He had a road built to the headwaters of LeBoeuf Creek. Marin constructed a second fort at Fort Le Boeuf (present-day Waterford, Pennsylvania), designed to guard the headwaters of LeBoeuf Creek. As he moved south, he drove off or captured British traders, alarming both the British and the Iroquois. Tanaghrisson, a chief of the Mingo, who were remnants of Iroquois and other tribes who had been driven west by colonial expansion. He intensely disliked the French (whom he accused of killing and eating his father). Traveling to Fort Le Boeuf, he threatened the French with military action, which Marin contemptuously dismissed.

Cnut's ambitious project to create a royal England, stretching from the Firth of Forth in the north to the mouth of the Severn in the south-west, and from the mouth of the Mersey in the north-west all the way across to the upper Thames valley in the east, has been taken as evidence that it was the well-meaning policy of one king. In truth, it was not the policy of one man, but rather a political platform developed over a century or so and sometimes sidelined. For the first two years of Cnut's reign, he left the management of affairs to his experienced earls, but gradually began making decisions on his own, sometimes on his own advice, other times based on new advice he sought. Eric Snare had returned to his homeland in 1022, and in the next few years a number of English exiles also returned. It is possible that Edwy, ealdorman of Mercia and Edgar's heir, was back by the autumn of 1024. Cnut had also moved his headquarters to Greenwich. In 1024 a Welsh rebel army invaded from the south-west, probably after being granted sanctuary by a king or earl who had so often supported rebels in the past that his early cooperation with the English king created unease. At one point the Welsh rebels split up, with one force of several hundred men marching all the way to Peterborough, no doubt with the intention of killing as many English as possible. But William the English ealdorman met the rebels there, and the fighting lasted only until dusk. The rest of the rebels then surrendered, and William ordered that they be sent to Norway, with the consent of their king Swein Estrithson. That same year Cnut's Danes also put down a rebellion in southern Shropshire. 320 men from northern Shropshire and southern Cheshire gathered at Caus castle, on the Essex border, probably hoping for assistance from the east country via Wales or from Shrewsbury or even Chester. In the summer of that year a fleet of 24 ships and several thousand soldiers came south, but the rebels were alarmed when they landed near Newton-on-Trent and moved quickly to surrender; they were then sent home by boat. Also that summer, an old comrade of the king's, Swein Estrithson, brought a Danish fleet to the Wash, apparently helping Cnut put down a rebellion in Norfolk and Lynn; Danes fought on both sides of the conflict. The rebels were killed or sold into slavery, and Swein decided to remain in England with a fleet of 32 ships, possibly hoping for a reward for his service, but he departed two years later.

What is the history of the Doctor Who?

The history of Doctor Who began with its first episode, "An Unearthly Child," which was broadcast on 23 November 1963. The show was created by Sydney Newman, who worked at the BBC as a production controller, and was produced by Verity Lambert.

The first series of Doctor Who was comprised of thirteen episodes, and was initially set in the 1960s. The show was directed by Jacobsen Frew and starred Christopher Ealing as the Doctor. However, Ealing had already been replaced by John Pertwee, who began appearing in the second series of the show as the First Doctor in "The Dalek Invasion of Earth."

The character of the Doctor was first introduced in the episode "An Unearthly Child," where he accompanies two young schoolgirls on a time travel adventure through different eras of history. The Doctor is initially portrayed as a humble, ordinary human, but soon reveals his extraordinary abilities and powers as a time traveler.

title: Pharmacy
context: Consultant pharmacy practice focuses more on medication regimen review (i.e. "cognitive services") than on actual dispensing of drugs. Consultant pharmacists most typically work in nursing homes, but are increasingly branching into other institutions and non-institutional settings. Traditionally consultant pharmacists were usually independent business owners, though in the United States many now work for several large pharmacy management companies (primarily Omnicare, Kindred Healthcare and PharMerica). This trend may be gradually reversing as consultant pharmacists begin to work directly with patients, primarily because many elderly people are now taking numerous medications but continue to live outside of institutional settings. Some community pharmacies employ consultant pharmacists and/or provide consulting services.

Roger Rocka's Dinner Theater & Good Company Players also opened nearby in 1978,[citation needed] at Olive and Wishon Avenues. Fresno native Audra McDonald performed in the leading roles of Evita and The Wiz at the theater while she was a high school student. McDonald subsequently became a leading performer on Broadway in New York City and a Tony award winning actress. Also in the Tower District is Good Company Players' 2nd Space Theatre.

title: Victoria and Albert Museum
context: The Victoria and Albert Museum (often abbreviated as the V&A), London, is the world's largest museum of decorative arts and design, housing a permanent collection of over 4.5 million objects. It was founded in 1852 and named after Queen Victoria and Prince Albert. The V&A is located in the Brompton district of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, in an area that has become known as "Albertopolis" because of its association with Prince Albert, the Albert Memorial and the major cultural institutions with which he was associated. These include the Natural History Museum, the Science Museum and the Royal Albert Hall. The museum is a non-departmental public body sponsored by the Department for Culture, Media and Sport. Like other national British museums, entrance to the museum has been free since 2001.

title: Computational complexity theory
context: But bounding the computation time above by some concrete function f(n) often yields complexity classes that depend on the chosen machine model. For instance, the language {xx | x is any binary string} can be solved in linear time on a multi-tape Turing machine, but necessarily requires quadratic time in the model of single-tape Turing machines. If we allow polynomial variations in running time, Cobham-Edmonds thesis states that "the time complexities in any two reasonable and general models of computation are polynomially related" (Goldreich 2008, Chapter 1.2). This forms the basis for the complexity class P, which is the set of decision problems solvable by a deterministic Turing machine within polynomial time. The corresponding set of function problems is FP.

It's easier to imagine a week going by than a year. That's because of the Framingham Study. Learn the tools it taught us to see the future, not fall into its traps

Passage:
Last week marked the 75th anniversary of the start of a medical study that involved people in the town of Framingham, Massachusetts. During those seven and a half decades, more than 12,000 people went through the Framingham Heart Study. To this day, it is still one of the most valuable tools doctors and researchers have for predicting your future healthâ€”and the future of medicine.
The study began in 1948 when a researcher approached the local government in Framingham with a plan to better understand the relationship between diet and health. After getting the blessings of city councilmen, researchers fanned out, gathering the names of 2,400 citizens between the ages of 30 and 62.
That was the beginning of the Framingham Heart Study. It would be 15 years before doctors got results, but within a couple of decades, those results changed the way people looked at their health and hearts forever. One of the early observations made by the Framingham researchers was that there was a connection between cholesterol and heart disease.
Over time, the researchers learned more about the link. They found that heart disease was not only related to cholesterol but also to whether someone was male, had high blood pressure, or had ever had a heart attack. (In Framingham, that had been the 10th leading cause of death at that time.)
The Framingham study has made important contributions to the field of medical research in a number of ways. According to researcher Brandeis, "It has helped us understand the factors that contribute to heart disease, which is the leading cause of death in the United States." Also, "The study has helped doctors identify and treat patients at risk for heart disease, which can help prevent heart attacks and strokes."
The Framingham study has also contributed to our understanding of how to prevent heart disease. According to Dr. Brandeis, "The study has helped doctors develop guidelines for healthy lifestyles, including diet, exercise, and smoking cessation." By doing this, the Framingham study has helped people improve their heart health and live longer, healthier lives.
But that's not the only thing the Framingham study has contributed to. It has also helped us understand the risks of other medical conditions. Researchers have found that people with high blood pressure are at increased risk for stroke and heart attack, and that people with diabetes are at increased risk for heart disease. The Framingham study has also contributed to our understanding of the importance of regular medical exams, as researchers have shown that early detection and treatment of medical conditions can help people live longer, healthier lives.
Overall, the Framingham study has been a valuable tool in helping us understand our health and the factors that contribute to disease. It has helped doctors develop better ways to prevent and treat medical conditions, and has helped us understand the risks associated with certain behaviors and lifestyles. The Framingham study is an important reminder that the small decisions we make every day can have a big impact on our health and longevity.
The Framingham study has also helped doctors identify and treat patients at risk for heart disease. Over the years, researchers have developed a series of equations and algorithms known as "risk scores" that help doctors assess a person's risk for developing heart disease based on factors such as age, sex, family history, and lifestyle. By using these risk scores, doctors can identify patients who are at high risk for heart disease and can then take steps to prevent or treat it.
One of the most important lessons that the Framingham study taught us is that the small decisions we make every day can have a big impact on our health and longevity. This is because the study showed that many of the factors that contribute to heart disease, such as high blood pressure and high cholesterol, can be controlled through lifestyle changes like diet and exercise. By making healthy choices every day, we can reduce our risk for heart disease and other medical conditions and live longer, healthier lives.

It has helped doctors develop better ways to prevent and treat medical conditions, and has helped us understand the risks associated with certain behaviors and lifestyles. The study is an important reminder that the small decisions we make every day can have a big impact on our health and longevity.

title: Packet switching
context: Baran developed the concept of distributed adaptive message block switching during his research at the RAND Corporation for the US Air Force into survivable communications networks, first presented to the Air Force in the summer of 1961 as briefing B-265, later published as RAND report P-2626 in 1962, and finally in report RM 3420 in 1964. Report P-2626 described a general architecture for a large-scale, distributed, survivable communications network. The work focuses on three key ideas: use of a decentralized network with multiple paths between any two points, dividing user messages into message blocks, later called packets, and delivery of these messages by store and forward switching.

title: Chloroplast
context: While photosystem II photolyzes water to obtain and energize new electrons, photosystem I simply reenergizes depleted electrons at the end of an electron transport chain. Normally, the reenergized electrons are taken by NADP+, though sometimes they can flow back down more H+-pumping electron transport chains to transport more hydrogen ions into the thylakoid space to generate more ATP. This is termed cyclic photophosphorylation because the electrons are recycled. Cyclic photophosphorylation is common in C4 plants, which need more ATP than NADPH.

In what process are electrons recycled?

What do C4 plants need?

completions:
1. Chloroplasts contain two types of photosystems, Photosystem II (PSII) and Photosystem I (PSI).
2. PSII is responsible for splitting water molecules to produce oxygen and free electrons.
3. PSII energizes new electrons, while PSI reenergizes depleted electrons.
4. Normally, reenergized electrons are taken by NADP+.
5. Cyclic photophosphorylation can occur when electrons flow back down more H+-pumping electron transport chains.
6. Cyclic photophosphorylation is less energy-efficient than non-cyclic photophosphorylation.
7. Cyclic photophosphorylation is common in C4 plants, which need more ATP than NADPH.
8. Non-cyclic photophosphorylation, where electrons are directly taken by NADP+, is more common in other plants.
9. The purpose of the electron transport chain is to generate ATP through the movement of protons across the thylakoid membrane.
10. Photosynthetic organisms use energy from sunlight to create ATP and NADPH, which are essential for cellular respiration and growth.

8. Cyclic photophosphorylation helps meet the energy demands of C4 plants by generating additional ATP.

title: Huguenot
context: Stadtholder William III of Orange, who later became King of England, emerged as the strongest opponent of king Louis XIV after the French attacked the Dutch Republic in 1672. William formed the League of Augsburg as a coalition to oppose Louis and the French state. Consequently, many Huguenots considered the wealthy and Calvinist Dutch Republic, which led the opposition to Louis XIV, as the most attractive country for exile after the revocation of the Edict of Nantes. They also found many French-speaking Calvinist churches there.

title: United Methodist Church
context: Though John Wesley originally wanted the Methodists to stay within the Church of England, the American Revolution decisively separated the Methodists in the American colonies from the life and sacraments of the Anglican Church. In 1784, after unsuccessful attempts to have the Church of England send a bishop to start a new church in the colonies, Wesley decisively appointed fellow priest Thomas Coke as superintendent (bishop) to organize a separate Methodist Society. Together with Coke, Wesley sent a revision of the Anglican Prayerbook and the Articles of Religion which were received and adopted by the Baltimore Christmas Conference of 1784, officially establishing the Methodist Episcopal Church. The conference was held at the Lovely Lane Methodist Church, considered the Mother Church of American Methodism.

questions.question: What caused the separation of the Methodists in the American colonies?
When did Wesley appoint Thomas Coke as bishop?
Who did Wesley appoint as bishop in 1784?
Where was the Baltimore Christmas Conference of 1784 held?
What is considered the Mother Church of American Methodism?

completions:
1. The American Revolution had a significant impact on the separation of the Methodists from the Church of England.
2. John Wesley originally wanted the Methodists to stay within the Church of England.
3. The Methodist Episcopal Church was officially established in 1784.
4. The creation of the Methodist Episcopal Church led to the separation of the Methodists from the Anglican Church.
5. Thomas Coke was appointed by John Wesley as the first bishop of the Methodist Episcopal Church.
6. The Baltimore Christmas Conference of 1784 received and adopted the revised Anglican Prayerbook and the Articles of Religion.
7. The Lovely Lane Methodist Church was considered the Mother Church of American Methodism.
8. The formation of the Methodist Episcopal Church marked the start of a new independent Christian denomination in the United States.
9. The Methodist Episcopal Church provided Methodists in the American colonies with their own leadership and structures.
10. The separation of the Methodists from the Anglican Church also marked the beginning of the Methodist movement, which would later grow to become one of the largest Christian denominations in the world.

United Methodist Church
The name for the new Methodist body came from a request made at the Christmas Conference: F. Asbury and T. Coke both declared themselves to be "general superintendents", a title used in Anglican choirs to indicate the senior layperson (Today the title is most often used for parish chairs or sextons). The Northern and Southern bishops immediately distanced themselves from the title. The title of superintendent has been used by all bishops of the UMC until today. Asbury's name is still the most revered in the church, and every new bishop since 1896 (except for Juan Luis Lascurain in 1996) has made a public declaration of loyalty to Asbury on the occasion of his or her consecration as a bishop.

United Methodist Church
On December 3, 1839, the first of several Northern-Southern splits occurred, over slavery and whether or not it was compatible with United Methodism. While the majority of United Methodists lived in the South, a significant minority also lived in the North. United Methodist Church
Though John Wesley originally wanted the Methodists to stay within the Church of England, the American Revolution decisively separated the Methodists in the American colonies from the life and sacraments of the Anglican Church. In 1784, after unsuccessful attempts to have the Church of England send a bishop to start a new church in the colonies, Wesley decisively appointed fellow priest Thomas Coke as superintendent (bishop) to organize a separate Methodist Society. Together with Coke, Wesley sent a revision of the Anglican Prayerbook and the Articles of Religion which were received and adopted by the Baltimore Christmas Conference of 1784, officially establishing the Methodist Episcopal Church. The conference was held at the Lovely Lane Methodist Church, considered the Mother Church of American Methodism.

title: Computational complexity theory
context: The graph isomorphism problem is the computational problem of determining whether two finite graphs are isomorphic. An important unsolved problem in complexity theory is whether the graph isomorphism problem is in P, NP-complete, or NP-intermediate. The answer is not known, but it is believed that the problem is at least not NP-complete. If graph isomorphism is NP-complete, the polynomial time hierarchy collapses to its second level. Since it is widely believed that the polynomial hierarchy does not collapse to any finite level, it is believed that graph isomorphism is not NP-complete. The best algorithm for this problem, due to Laszlo Babai and Eugene Luks has run time 2O(âˆš(n log(n))) for graphs with n vertices.

title: Nikola Tesla
context: On 11 July 1934, the New York Herald Tribune published an article on Tesla, in which he recalled an event that would occasionally take place while experimenting with his single-electrode vacuum tubes; a minute particle would break off the cathode, pass out of the tube, and physically strike him. "Tesla said he could feel a sharp stinging pain where it entered his body, and again at the place where it passed out." In comparing these particles with the bits of metal projected by his "electric gun," Tesla said, "The particles in the beam of force ... will travel much faster than such particles ... and they will travel in concentrations."

prompt:
Let's read the following passage and produce a long list of implications derived directly or indirectly from the content.

Passage:
Nikola Tesla
On 11 July 1934, the New York Herald Tribune published an article on Tesla, in which he recalled an event that would occasionally take place while experimenting with his single-electrode vacuum tubes; a minute particle would break off the cathode, pass out of the tube, and physically strike him. "Tesla said he could feel a sharp stinging pain where it entered his body, and again at the place where it passed out." In comparing these particles with the bits of metal projected by his "electric gun," Tesla said, "The particles in the beam of force ... will travel much faster than such particles ... and they will travel in concentrations."

title: Martin Luther
context: In accordance with his father's wishes, Luther enrolled in law school at the same university that year but dropped out almost immediately, believing that law represented uncertainty. Luther sought assurances about life and was drawn to theology and philosophy, expressing particular interest in Aristotle, William of Ockham, and Gabriel Biel. He was deeply influenced by two tutors, Bartholomaeus Arnoldi von Usingen and Jodocus Trutfetter, who taught him to be suspicious of even the greatest thinkers and to test everything himself by experience. Philosophy proved to be unsatisfying, offering assurance about the use of reason but none about loving God, which to Luther was more important. Reason could not lead men to God, he felt, and he thereafter developed a love-hate relationship with Aristotle over the latter's emphasis on reason. For Luther, reason could be used to question men and institutions, but not God. Human beings could learn about God only through divine revelation, he believed, and Scripture therefore became increasingly important to him.

Joe Barton, chairman of the House Committee on Energy and Commerce wrote joint letters with Ed Whitfield, Chairman of the Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations demanding full records on climate research, as well as personal information about their finances and careers, from Mann, Bradley and Hughes. Sherwood Boehlert, chairman of the House Science Committee, said this was a "misguided and illegitimate investigation" apparently aimed at intimidating scientists, and at his request the U.S. National Academy of Sciences arranged for its National Research Council to set up a special investigation. The National Research Council's report agreed that there were some statistical failings, but these had little effect on the graph, which was generally correct. In a 2006 letter to Nature, Mann, Bradley, and Hughes pointed out that their original article had said that "more widespread high-resolution data are needed before more confident conclusions can be reached" and that the uncertainties were "the point of the article".

Marshall Space Center in Huntsville, Alabama, Michoud Assembly Facility in New Orleans, Louisiana, and Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center in Houston, Texas.

Consider the problem from another point of view. Let's say that the two trips the ship did across the lake  were only 1 way. If then we calculate the average speed of the ship from A to B and from B to A using the above-mentioned formula, will we get the same average speed. Otherwise, how does one get from the raw data that tells about the ship's speeds on its two one way trips, the ship's speed on its round trip from A to B and then from B to A.

If the two trips across the lake were only one-way and we calculate the average speed using the formula mentioned in the previous explanation, we would not get the same average speed for the ship's journey from A to B and from B to A. The average speed calculation depends on the total distance traveled and the total time taken.

To get the ship's speed on its round trip from A to B and then from B to A, you can follow these steps:

1. Determine the distances of the one-way trips: Let's call the distance from A to B "d1" and the distance from B to A "d2."
2. Find the time taken for each one-way trip: Let's call the time taken for the trip from A to B "t1" and the time taken for the trip from B to A "t2."
3. Calculate the total distance for the round trip: This would be d1 + d2.
4. Calculate the total time for the round trip: This would be t1 + t2.
5. Use the average speed formula: average speed = (total distance) / (total time).
6. Plug in the values from steps 3 and 4 into the formula to get the ship's average speed for the round trip.

So, if you have the distances and times for each one-way trip, you can use this method to determine the average speed for the ship's round trip.

The summation of the two times of two one-way trips is only the total time of the round trip, but this does not allow us to get the round trip average speed as the sum of individual one-way trips' speeds.

You are correct. My previous response was misleading. To clarify:

To find the average speed of the ship on its round trip from A to B and then from B to A, you need to use the total distance traveled (sum of the distances for each one-way trip) and the total time taken (sum of the times for each one-way trip).

Using the formula for average speed:

average speed = (total distance) / (total time)

Where:
- The total distance is the sum of the distances for the trip from A to B (d1) and the trip from B to A (d2).
- The total time is the sum of the times for the trip from A to B (t1) and the trip from B to A (t2).

By calculating the total distance and total time, you can then determine the average speed for the round trip. The summation of the two times of the two one-way trips does not directly provide the total time for the round trip; it only represents the sum of the individual one-way times.

Show that if $x$ is rational and $y$ is irrational, then $x + y$ and $xy$ are irrational.

To show that if \( x \) is rational and \( y \) is irrational, then \( x + y \) and \( xy \) are irrational, we will use a proof by contradiction.

### Part 1: Proving \( x + y \) is irrational

1. **Assume the contrary**: Suppose \( x + y \) is rational.
2. **Rationality of \( x \)**: Since \( x \) is rational, we can write \( x \) as \( \frac{a}{b} \) where \( a \) and \( b \) are integers and \( b \neq 0 \).
3. **Rationality of \( x + y \)**: By our assumption, \( x + y \) can be written as \( \frac{c}{d} \) where \( c \) and \( d \) are integers and \( d \neq 0 \).
4. **Isolate \( y \)**: From \( x + y = \frac{c}{d} \), we can solve for \( y \):
   \[
   y = \frac{c}{d} - x = \frac{c}{d} - \frac{a}{b}
   \]
5. **Combine fractions**: Find a common denominator to combine the fractions:
   \[
   y = \frac{bc - ad}{bd}
   \]

Circadian system
During this time, the pineal gland senses darkness and secretes melatonin, thus increasing its concentration in the blood. Shift work that reverses the daily pattern of light and darkness over months or years can lead to chronic sleep disorders. Light therapy utilizing bright lights or light visors can be used to reduce seasonal depression.

- Bright light therapy can be used as a treatment for seasonal depression, as it mimics exposure to natural light.

title: Fresno, California
context: Homes from the early 20th century line this boulevard in the heart of the historic Alta Vista Tract. The section of Huntington Boulevard between First Street on the west to Cedar Avenue on the east is the home to many large, stately homes. The original development of this area began circa 1910, on 190 acres of what had been an alfalfa field. The Alta Vista Tract, as the land would become known, was mapped by William Stranahan for the Pacific Improvement Corporation, and was officially platted in 1911. The tract's boundaries were Balch Avenue on the south, Cedar Avenue on the east, the rear property line of Platt Avenue (east of Sixth Street) and Platt Avenue (west of Sixth Street) on the north, and First Street on the west. The subdivision was annexed to the City in January 1912, in an election that was the first in which women voted in the community. At the time of its admission to the City, the Alta Vista Tract was uninhabited but landscaped, although the trees had to be watered by tank wagon. In 1914 developers Billings & Meyering acquired the tract, completed street development, provided the last of the necessary municipal improvements including water service, and began marketing the property with fervor. A mere half decade later the tract had 267 homes. This rapid development was no doubt hastened by the Fresno Traction Company right-of-way along Huntington Boulevard, which provided streetcar connections between downtown and the County Hospital.

Explain the concept of entropy in thermodynamics, including the second law of thermodynamics and its implications.

Entropy is a measure of the degree of disorder or randomness in a system. In thermodynamics, it is defined as a state function, meaning its value depends only on the current state of the system, not on how it was reached. The second law of thermodynamics states that the total entropy of an isolated system always increases over time or stays the same, it never decreases. This law implies that processes in nature tend to move towards a state of maximum entropy, or maximum disorder. This is because it is easier for atoms to move randomly and scatter than it is for them to order themselves in a specific way. The second law has important implications for understanding energy transfer and the efficiency of energy conversion processes, as well as the concept of heat death, where the universe reaches a state of maximum entropy and all energy is evenly distributed, making further energy transfer impossible.

To prove that the matrix \(\mathbf{S}\) is always positive semidefinite, we need to show that for any vector \(\mathbf{v} \in \mathbb{R}^{n+m}\), the quadratic form \(\mathbf{v}^T \mathbf{S} \mathbf{v} \geq 0\).

\[

\[

\]
where \(\mathbf{L} = \left( X^T W X \right)^{-1}\).

Then, we have:
\[
\mathbf{S} = \mathbf{B}^{-1} \mathbf{A} \mathbf{B}^{-T}
\]

Since \(\mathbf{B}\) is a diagonal matrix with \(\mathbf{L}\) on the diagonal, its inverse is:
\[
\mathbf{B}^{-1} = \begin{pmatrix} \mathbf{L}^{-1} & 0 \\ 0 & \mathbf{L}^{-1} \end{pmatrix}
\]

Thus,
\[
\mathbf{S} = \begin{pmatrix} \mathbf{L}^{-1} & 0 \\ 0 & \mathbf{L}^{-1} \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} X^T W X & X^T W Z \\ Z^T W X & Z^T W Z \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} \mathbf{L}^{-1} & 0 \\ 0 & \mathbf{L}^{-1} \end{pmatrix}
\]

This simplifies to:
\[

\]

\[

\]

This expands to:

\]

Let's read the following passage and produce a long list of implications derived directly or indirectly from the content.

Passage:
Fresno, California
Homes from the early 20th century line this boulevard in the heart of the historic Alta Vista Tract. The section of Huntington Boulevard between First Street on the west to Cedar Avenue on the east is the home to many large, stately homes. The original development of this area began circa 1910, on 190 acres of what had been an alfalfa field. The Alta Vista Tract, as the land would become known, was mapped by William Stranahan for the Pacific Improvement Corporation, and was officially platted in 1911. The tract's boundaries were Balch Avenue on the south, Cedar Avenue on the east, the rear property line of Platt Avenue (east of Sixth Street) and Platt Avenue (west of Sixth Street) on the north, and First Street on the west. The subdivision was annexed to the City in January 1912, in an election that was the first in which women voted in the community. At the time of its admission to the City, the Alta Vista Tract was uninhabited but landscaped, although the trees had to be watered by tank wagon. In 1914 developers Billings & Meyering acquired the tract, completed street development, provided the last of the necessary municipal improvements including water service, and began marketing the property with fervor. A mere half decade later the tract had 267 homes. This rapid development was no doubt hastened by the Fresno Traction Company right-of-way along Huntington Boulevard, which provided streetcar connections between downtown and the County Hospital.

title: Martin Luther
context: Martin Luther was born to Hans Luder (or Ludher, later Luther) and his wife Margarethe (nÃ©e Lindemann) on 10 November 1483 in Eisleben, Saxony, then part of the Holy Roman Empire. He was baptized as a Catholic the next morning on the feast day of St. Martin of Tours. His family moved to Mansfeld in 1484, where his father was a leaseholder of copper mines and smelters and served as one of four citizen representatives on the local council. The religious scholar Martin Marty describes Luther's mother as a hard-working woman of "trading-class stock and middling means" and notes that Luther's enemies later wrongly described her as a whore and bath attendant. He had several brothers and sisters, and is known to have been close to one of them, Jacob. Hans Luther was ambitious for himself and his family, and he was determined to see Martin, his eldest son, become a lawyer. He sent Martin to Latin schools in Mansfeld, then Magdeburg in 1497, where he attended a school operated by a lay group called the Brethren of the Common Life, and Eisenach in 1498. The three schools focused on the so-called "trivium": grammar, rhetoric, and logic. Luther later compared his education there to purgatory and hell.
